regulation_detail: Incoterms (International Commercial Terms) are a set of globally recognized rules defining buyer and seller responsibilities in international trade.
Incoterms provide a framework for understanding the division of responsibilities between buyer and seller.
Incoterms clarify the allocation of costs associated with the delivery of goods between buyer and seller.
Incoterms define the point at which the risk of loss or damage to goods transfers from seller to buyer.
Incoterms rules are published by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC).
Incoterms are not mandatory laws; they are guidelines parties mutually agree upon in a contract.
Correct application of Incoterms is critical for containerized multimodal transport to avoid misunderstandings and ensure smooth transit.
Under EXW, the seller's primary obligation is to make goods available to the buyer at the named place (typically seller's premises).
Under EXW, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been made available by the seller at the named place.
Under EXW, the buyer is responsible for arranging and executing the loading of goods at the seller's premises.
Under EXW, the buyer is responsible for handling and paying for all export formalities in the seller's country.
Under EXW, the buyer is responsible for contracting and paying for all carriage from the seller's premises onwards.
Under EXW, the buyer is responsible for handling and paying for import clearance in the destination country.
Under FCA, the seller delivers the goods to the carrier or another person nominated by the buyer at the named place.
Under FCA, if delivery occurs at the seller's premises, the seller is responsible for loading the goods onto the buyer's collecting vehicle.
Under FCA, if delivery occurs at another named place (not seller's premises), the seller delivers goods ready for unloading from their means of transport.
Under FCA, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under FCA, the buyer is responsible for contracting and paying for the main carriage from the named place of delivery.
Under FCA, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under FAS, the seller delivers the goods by placing them alongside the vessel nominated by the buyer at the named port of shipment.
Under FAS, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under FAS, the buyer must nominate the vessel for carriage.
Under FAS, the buyer contracts and pays for the main carriage from the port of shipment.
Under FAS, the buyer is responsible for loading the goods onto the ship from alongside the vessel.
Under FAS, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under FOB, the seller delivers the goods by placing them on board the vessel nominated by the buyer at the named port of shipment.
Under FOB, the seller is responsible for loading the goods on board the vessel.
Under FOB, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under FOB, the buyer must nominate the vessel for carriage.
Under FOB, the buyer contracts and pays for the main carriage from the port of shipment.
Under FOB, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under CPT, the seller delivers the goods to the first carrier nominated by the seller at an agreed place.
Under CPT, the seller contracts and pays for the carriage of goods to the named place of destination.
Under CPT, the seller is responsible for arranging the loading of the goods onto the first carrier.
Under CPT, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under CPT, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller to the first carrier.
Under CPT, the buyer is typically responsible for unloading goods at the named destination, unless unloading is included in the seller's carriage contract.
Under CPT, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under CIP, the seller delivers the goods to the first carrier nominated by the seller at an agreed place.
Under CIP, the seller contracts and pays for the carriage of goods to the named place of destination.
Under CIP, the seller must obtain and pay for cargo insurance covering the buyer's risk during carriage to the destination.
Under CIP, the seller is responsible for arranging the loading of the goods onto the first carrier.
Under CIP, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under CIP, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller to the first carrier.
Under CIP, the buyer is typically responsible for unloading goods at the named destination, unless unloading is included in the seller's carriage contract.
Under CIP, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under CFR, the seller delivers the goods by placing them on board the vessel at the port of shipment.
Under CFR, the seller is responsible for loading the goods on board the vessel.
Under CFR, the seller contracts and pays for the carriage (freight) of goods to the named port of destination.
Under CFR, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under CFR, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller on board the vessel.
Under CFR, the buyer is responsible for unloading the goods at the named port of destination.
Under CFR, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under CIF, the seller delivers the goods by placing them on board the vessel at the port of shipment.
Under CIF, the seller is responsible for loading the goods on board the vessel.
Under CIF, the seller contracts and pays for the carriage (freight) of goods to the named port of destination.
Under CIF, the seller must obtain and pay for minimum cover cargo insurance against the buyer's risk during carriage.
Under CIF, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under CIF, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller on board the vessel.
Under CIF, the buyer is responsible for unloading the goods at the named port of destination.
Under CIF, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under DAP, the seller delivers the goods when they are placed at the buyer's disposal on the arriving means of transport, ready for unloading at the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the seller contracts and pays for carriage to the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under DAP, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller at the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the buyer is responsible for unloading the goods from the arriving means of transport at the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under DPU, the seller delivers the goods once unloaded from the arriving means of transport at the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the seller contracts and pays for carriage to the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the seller is responsible for unloading the goods at the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under DPU, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered (unloaded) by the seller at the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the buyer is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities.
Under DDP, the seller delivers goods cleared for import, placed at the buyer's disposal on arriving means of transport, ready for unloading at the named place of destination.
Under DDP, the seller contracts and pays for carriage to the named place of destination.
Under DDP, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for export clearance formalities.
Under DDP, the seller is responsible for carrying out and paying for import clearance formalities, including duties and taxes.
Under DDP, the buyer must take delivery of the goods when they have been delivered by the seller at the named place of destination.
Under DDP, the buyer is typically responsible for unloading the goods at the final destination.
Under EXW, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport, unless specific packaging is agreed otherwise.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of loading the goods onto their collecting vehicle at the seller's premises.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under EXW, the buyer bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight).
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under EXW, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under FCA, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under FCA, if delivery is at the seller's premises, the seller bears the cost of loading goods onto the buyer's collecting vehicle.
Under FCA, origin THC costs are borne by seller or buyer depending on the agreed named place of delivery (before or after THC point).
Under FCA, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) from the named place of delivery.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under FCA, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under FAS, the seller bears the cost of checking, packaging, and marking required for delivery alongside.
Under FAS, the seller bears all costs until the goods are placed alongside the vessel at the port of shipment.
Under FAS, the seller typically bears costs associated with bringing goods to the quay/barge, implicitly including origin handling up to that point.
Under FAS, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of loading the goods onto the vessel from alongside.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight).
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under FAS, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under FOB, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under FOB, the seller bears all costs until the goods are loaded on board the vessel.
Under FOB, the seller typically bears the origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under FOB, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods onto the vessel.
Under FOB, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight).
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination.
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination.
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under FOB, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under FOB, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under CPT, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under CPT, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CPT, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods onto the first carrier.
source_section: CPT A9 / Guidance Note [Source 19 implies, Table assumes]

regulation_detail: Under CPT, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under CPT, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) to the named destination.
Under CPT, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under CPT, the seller bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC), as part of carriage to destination.
Under CPT, the buyer typically bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination, unless included in seller's contract.
Under CPT, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final named destination, unless included in the contract of carriage.
Under CPT, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination (beyond the named place if different).
Under CPT, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under CPT, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods onto the first carrier.
source_section: CIP A9 / Guidance Note [Source 22 implies, Table assumes]

regulation_detail: Under CIP, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) to the named destination.
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of obtaining the mandatory cargo insurance.
Under CIP, the seller bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC), as part of carriage to destination.
Under CIP, the buyer typically bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) at destination, unless included in seller's contract.
Under CIP, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final named destination, unless included in the contract of carriage.
Under CIP, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination (beyond the named place if different).
Under CIP, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under CIP, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under CFR, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under CFR, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CFR, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods onto the vessel.
Under CFR, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under CFR, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (freight) to the named destination port.
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of any cargo insurance (seller has no obligation).
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (vessel) at the destination port.
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination (if different from port unloading).
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under CFR, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under CFR, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under CIF, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under CIF, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CIF, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods onto the vessel.
Under CIF, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under CIF, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (freight) to the named destination port.
Under CIF, the seller bears the cost of obtaining the mandatory minimum cover cargo insurance.
Under CIF, the buyer bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC).
Under CIF, the buyer bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (vessel) at the destination port.
Under CIF, the buyer bears the cost of unloading at the final destination (if different from port unloading).
Under CIF, the buyer bears the cost of inland haulage at the destination.
Under CIF, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under CIF, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods at the origin.
source_section: DAP A9 / Guidance Note [Source 34 implies, Table assumes]

regulation_detail: Under DAP, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) to the named destination.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of insurance only if they choose to insure the shipment (no obligation).
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC), as part of carriage.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) if it is part of the contract of carriage to the named place.
Under DAP, the buyer bears the cost of unloading the goods from the arriving means of transport at the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the seller bears the cost of inland haulage to the named place of destination.
Under DAP, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under DAP, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods at the origin.
source_section: DPU A9 / Guidance Note [Source 38 implies, Table assumes]

regulation_detail: Under DPU, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) to the named destination.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of insurance only if they choose to insure the shipment (no obligation).
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC), as part of carriage.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) if it is part of the contract of carriage to the named place.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of unloading the goods at the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the seller bears the cost of inland haulage to the named place of destination.
Under DPU, the buyer bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under DPU, the buyer bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of packaging necessary for transport.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of origin terminal handling charges (THC).
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of loading the goods at the origin.
source_section: DDP A9 / Guidance Note [Source 42 implies, Table assumes]

regulation_detail: Under DDP, the seller bears the costs associated with export formalities.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of the main carriage (e.g., ocean freight) to the named destination.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of insurance only if they choose to insure the shipment (no obligation).
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of destination terminal handling charges (THC), as part of carriage.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of unloading from the main carriage (e.g., vessel) if it is part of the contract of carriage to the named place.
Under DDP, the buyer bears the cost of unloading the goods from the arriving means of transport at the named place of destination.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of inland haulage to the named place of destination.
Under DDP, the seller bears the costs associated with import clearance.
Under DDP, the seller bears the cost of import duties and taxes.
Under EXW, risk transfers to the buyer when goods are made available at the seller's premises (or named place), ready for loading.
Under FCA, risk transfers to the buyer when the seller hands over the goods to the carrier (or nominated person) at the agreed named place.
Under FAS, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods have been placed alongside the nominated vessel at the named port of shipment.
Under FOB, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods are loaded on board the nominated vessel at the named port of shipment.
Under CPT, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods are handed over to the first carrier nominated by the seller.
Under CIP, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods are handed over to the first carrier nominated by the seller.
Under CFR, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods are loaded on board the vessel at the port of shipment.
Under CIF, risk transfers to the buyer when the goods are loaded on board the vessel at the port of shipment.
Under DAP, risk transfers to the buyer when goods are placed at their disposal on arriving means of transport, ready for unloading at the named destination.
Under DPU, risk transfers to the buyer once the goods are unloaded from the arriving means of transport at the named place of destination.
Under DDP, risk transfers to the buyer when goods (cleared for import) are placed at their disposal on arriving means of transport, ready for unloading at the named destination.
EXW (Ex Works) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
FCA (Free Carrier) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
FAS (Free Alongside Ship) is applicable only to sea or inland waterway transport.
FOB (Free On Board) is applicable only to sea or inland waterway transport.
CPT (Carriage Paid To) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
CIP (Carriage and Insurance Paid To) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
CFR (Cost and Freight) is applicable only to sea or inland waterway transport.
CIF (Cost, Insurance and Freight) is applicable only to sea or inland waterway transport.
DAP (Delivered At Place) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
DPU (Delivered at Place Unloaded) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) is applicable to any mode or modes of transport.
EXW (Ex Works) is generally discouraged for international container shipments due to buyer export complexities.
FCA (Free Carrier) is versatile, suitable for multimodal shipments involving containers, and often preferred over EXW.
FAS (Free Alongside Ship) is not suitable for container shipments; it is designed for bulk or non-containerized goods placed alongside a vessel.
FOB (Free On Board) is generally not recommended for containerized goods as containers are usually delivered to yards, not loaded directly.
CPT (Carriage Paid To) can be used for any mode of transport, including containerized and multimodal shipments.
CIP (Carriage and Insurance Paid To) is suitable for all modes of transport, including multimodal container shipments.
CFR (Cost and Freight) is generally not recommended for container shipments; CPT is considered a better alternative.
While CIF (Cost, Insurance and Freight) can be applied to containerized shipments, CPT or CIP might be more advantageous for most container exports.
DAP (Delivered At Place) is suitable for all modes of transport, including containerized and multimodal shipments.
DPU (Delivered at Place Unloaded) is suitable for all modes of transport, including containerized and multimodal shipments.
DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) is suitable for all modes of transport, including containerized and multimodal shipments.
Sea/Waterway terms (FAS, FOB, CFR, CIF) are often less suitable for containers as risk transfer at/before loading onto vessel doesn't align with terminal handling.
For container shipments, it is generally recommended to use Incoterms designed for any mode of transport (EXW, FCA, CPT, CIP, DAP, DPU, DDP).
Under CIP, the seller has a mandatory obligation to obtain cargo insurance for the buyer's benefit.
Under CIP (Incoterms 2020), the required insurance level is typically Institute Cargo Clauses (A) or similar high-level cover.
Under CIP, the insurance coverage obtained by the seller must be for at least 110% of the invoice value.
Under CIP, the insurance obtained by the seller must cover the buyer's risk of loss or damage during carriage.
Under CIF, the seller has a mandatory obligation to obtain minimum cover cargo insurance for the buyer's benefit.
Under CIF (Incoterms 2020), the default required insurance level is minimum cover, typically Institute Cargo Clauses (C).
Under CIF, the insurance coverage obtained by the seller must be for at least 110% of the invoice value.
Under CIF, the insurance obtained by the seller must cover the buyer's risk of loss or damage during the sea voyage.
For Incoterms other than CIF and CIP, the seller has no obligation to arrange cargo insurance.
source_section: General Guidance / A5 for other terms

regulation_detail: Buyers using CIF should be aware the minimum cover may be insufficient and might need to arrange additional insurance.
A significant challenge for the buyer under EXW is handling complex export formalities in the seller's country.
Even if buyer manages export under EXW, the seller might still be legally considered the exporter of record.
Under FCA, it is crucial to clearly define the agreed place and point of delivery in the contract to avoid misunderstandings.
A potential challenge for the seller under FAS arises if the nominated vessel is delayed, as seller retains risk until goods are alongside.
Under FAS, the buyer needs to ensure the nominated vessel has the capability to load the goods from alongside (quay/barge).
A significant challenge with FOB for containers is that goods are usually delivered to container yards, not directly loaded onto a vessel.
Using FOB for container shipments can create ambiguity about when risk and responsibility actually transfer.
A common point of confusion with CPT is the distinction between the place of delivery (risk transfer) and the named place of destination (cost endpoint).
Buyers using CIP should ensure the insurance coverage obtained by the seller is adequate for their specific needs, despite the ICC(A) requirement.
Under CFR, confusion can arise as risk transfers early (on board) while the seller continues to pay freight to the destination port.
Under CIF, the seller-provided minimum insurance coverage (ICC C) may be insufficient for the buyer's needs.
Buyers using DAP need to be prepared to handle the unloading of goods from the arriving means of transport.
A potential challenge with DPU arises if import clearance (buyer's task) is required before unloading (seller's task) can occur.
A significant challenge for sellers using DDP is the potential need to register for import and VAT/GST purposes in the buyer's country.
While convenient for the buyer, DDP can result in a higher overall cost as the seller includes all expenses and risk contingency in their price.
